author: sky.cactus
content: The fact that we are reducing profitability from a similar attack vector that we don't see by more than we are increasing profitability from a new attack vector makes me OK with launching 1559 as-is and considering a separate EIP for addressing the selfish fork choice rule problem.

author: sky.cactus
content:
Idea from a discussion thread elsewhere:
Have a 1559-like mechanism that targets a certain amount of new state per block and adjusts state write prices up/down based on that.  We would then reduce the regular gas cost of state writes to just the "cost of a node to write to disk" and we would not charge regular gas for the "state growth impact".

author: sky.cactus
content: There would be no inclusion fee component to this since it is a socialized cost, not an uncle risk for miners.  I don't believe we would need a new transaction type, as the max_fee can already account for this.

author: sky.cactus
content: It would just be an adjustment to the fee deduction algorithm and probably a new field in blocks.

author: sky.cactus
content: We could set the adjustment speed to be really slow if we wanted so seasonality had less of an effect.

author: query0x
content: Was consideration given to initially burning a small portion of the base fee and increasing the percentage over time?

author: sky.cactus
content: It was discussed, but the core devs don't seem to think it will provide any meaningful security benefits.

author: query0x
content: Is it, in any way, detrimental to securtiy?

author: sky.cactus
content: Only if the sudden reward reduction results in a sufficient incentive to attack the network.

author: query0x
content: Then, that would seem like a reasonable way to move the important goals of 1559 forward while treating miners a little less like adversaries and more as valued members of the changing Ethereum ecosystem.  With some certainty around the phase-out period, miners can plan operations accordingly and I suspect there would be much less opposition or animosity.
